div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,551] ALEXANDRIA, SATURDAY, JULY 21, 1906. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday until 4 June, and then every Tuesday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.

The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. Combined fare to London by sea and train de luxe via Brindisi or via Maresilles £194.11.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: The Engish Daily Newspaper, Established 1886
Editor and Manager - - R. SMELLING
ONE PLASTRE TARIFF
Saturday, July 21, 1906.
THE TABAH BLUE BOOK

For Anglo Egyptian* by far the most interesting sections of the Bine Book dealing with the Turco Egyptian frontier dispute are Lord Cromer's Note, dated May 21, on the attitude of the Moslem population of Egypt towards Great Britain in conception with the Frontier Question, and the remarkable letter, apparently written by a Turkish 'alim, enclosed there- with. The admirable translation of this document, which, we imagine, is the work of Mr. H. Boyle, adds a literary charm to an extra- ordinarily interesting expression of Pan-lslamio sentiment, and we commend this document to all who are under the impression that religions motives have no part in the unrest that has been remarked in Egypt during the last few months.

The Notes forwards 1 to Sir Edward Grey both by Sir Nicholas O'Conor and by Lori Cromer are of great importance. Ы. В M.'s Ambassador at Constantinople, in his Note of May 3, states that the Saltan, early in March, hid evinced a remarkable suspicion of British designs on Akaba, which, from its proximity to the Holy Places of 1 dam, is of great political л-id strategical importance. Lord Cromer explains that this suspicion on the part of his Imperial Maj »ty had its origin in the fictions industriously spread by the Pan-lslamio Press of Cairo.

The attitude of the Turkish Commanders and of the Tarkish Government was equally menacing. The Grand Vizier, telegraphing towards the end of January to the Khedive, had remarked—inter a/ta—"that if Egypt persisted in landing men and in constructing posts [This despatch was sent shortly after the arrival of the Nonr elBahr at Tabah] snob an act of disobedieoce would necessitate the employment of strong measures of ехраЫоп/' The story of the Diana's arrival off Akaba, the determined attitude of that fine type of Tarkish soldier, Eashdi Pasha, the extraordinary behavior of the Tarkish commissioners, and the defection of two Bedoain sheikhs, are all given, and we note with some amazement that the date palm* at Tabah which were said to belong to inhabitants of Akaba were only six or seven in number and were "all dead."

The claims advanced by the Porte in April through the intermediary of Mukhtar Pasba 1 converted the question from a purely local 1 dispute to a deliberate attempt to oarry tbs Turkish borders to the Saez CanaL The unbending attitude of the Ghati and the Turkish cooptation of Rafah brought matters to a head, and the British Ultimatum of May 3 left to the Porte the decision between peace and war. It is worth noting that while throughout the dispute the attitude of the Porte had been I the reverse of conciliatory the political development of the attack on Egypt had completely outrun the Turkish military preparations. A raid was possible in the early days of May, but its execution would have been attended with grave difficulties and its failure would probably have involved the otter destruction of the raiders. Mukhtar Pasha's three Corps d'Armée were in no position to under- take an immediate campaign against Egypt.

The attitude of the Great Powers daring the oourseof the dispute was eminently satisfactory. Sir N. O'Conor particularly mentions the sup- m port rendered by the French, Russian, Italian, and American Ambassadors, while, whatever may be said of certain irresponsible German editors and "agents," the fact that the German Ambassador warmly and publicly congratulated Sir N.O'Conor on the success of the negotiations in the presence of the other representatives of the Powers, should dispel the belief that, on this occasion, the policy of the German Empire was directed against Great a Britain. K

We propose on another occasion to reproduce in fall Lord Cromer's remarks concerning the Pan-lslamio Press. Meanwhile we com- mend the following epigram to the notice of Mustapha Pasha Kamel and the editor of that most sensational journal "Al Omma" "The id Pan-lslamio Press is not the mouthpiece of opinions that exist. It creates, by every process te of misrepresentation, opinions which would otherwise be non existent,"
Today's plague bulletin records fatal case at Alexandria and an admission to hospital at Suez.
The service to-morrow morning at 10.30 will be conducted by the Rev. Dr. Qifl'en, of the American Mission, Cairo.
The annual exhibition and distribution of prizes in St. Andrew's upper girls' school will take place on Monday next at 4 p.m.
The imports of coal from January 1 to July 19 amounted to 644,053 tons, as against 492,929 tons during the same period last year.
Thrее days ago a young, native woman of the Sayeda Naffeesa quarter, Cairo, took a draught of potassium, which ehemistock for some medicine, and succumbed in a few hours.

A partial eclipse of the sun will take place to-day. It will be invisible in Egypt but visible in the northern part of South America and Greenland, as well as in the northern part of Asia and the Pacific Ocean.

The Ministry of the Interior intends to add .Je district of El Marg and Zeitonn, hitherto administered by Ealioubieh Moodirieb, and the western part of Ghizth, to the thirteen kisms under the administration of the Cairo Governorate.

The stay of the Italian opera company at the Alhambra is drawing to a dose. This evening, Aida will be given. To morrow, II Barbiere di Siviglia will be given in the afternoon and Gioconda in the evening. The company will give their last performance on Monday, when La Bohème will be staged.

By the courtesy of the Egyptian Museum authorities, military people entering the Museum with the;Rev. E. J. Hardy, C. F., at 9.30 a.m. on Wednesdays, are admitted free Next Wednesday, Lieub-Col. Atkinson will point out the mummios of the Pharaohs mentioned in the Bible, and give a short account of their life and times, etc.

A Japanese sailor was attacked yesterday evening near the Marina by two natives, who attempted to rob bim. During the struggle a British soldier appeared and the allies took the two thieves prisoners to the Marina Coastguard station. The prisoners were forwarded to the Minet el-Bassal caracol, where an enquiry is now being held.

As already announced, the inauguration of the new theatre will take place t hie evening. Tomorrow morning at 10.30 the Bracelet orchestra will give a consort. Signi. Luoohini and Cairo and Signa. Ale°ei will take part in tin programme and will give for the first time the "Tiio dei Lombard'," preceded by a violin solo. The programme will end up with the overtore from "Tannhaneer.''

A great attraction to Cairo residents was the military concert on the terrace of the Grand Continental Hotel on Wednesday evening. A large crowd of people came to spend the evening in the open air, the restaurant was quite full, and a large number of dinners were served on well de jorated tables. The management has arranged another military concert for Wednesday next, from 8 to 11 p.m.

In the present dearth of places of amusement in Alexandria the opening of the "French Garden" to the public as a café ohantant aud promenade should be welcomed by a'l who are désirons of spending a pleasant hour or two in the cool of the evening. The garden has been prettily decorated with garlands, Hags, and hundreds of ebotrio lamps, and no pains have been spared to make the place comfortable arid a popular resort. The performance is of a varied nature and includes some excellent 1 turns," ânsong which may be mentioned Les Frères Bonnes, who executed some marvelous acrobatic feats of strength, La belle Clemence, curd Mandroux, who gave a really first-class gymnastic display. The four Salvanos are youngsters who are more than at home on cycles and who well merited the hearty applause aaoorded. The Moustiers gavo quite a novel performance, introducing dogs dressed as elephants. These are wonder- fully well trained, and their various tricks were much appreciated. The Takitos' droll rendering of their songs created considerable amusement. Other good items were contributediby Miss Ella, on the slack wire, Evariste au excellent xylophone player, the Sisters Gliickstern, singers and dancers, and Miles Corregioli and Melina de Gay, voca'ists. The oroheetra, under the direction of Mr. Enrico Santini, waie well op to their work, and the absence of any objeotionable waits between the turns added to the success of the enter- tainment, which was altogether a most enjoyable one. We can safely predict a prosperous season for tke troupe.

The British Chamber of Commerce gives notice that it has commenced an employment register, which may be consulted by members requiring clerical or other assistance. Applications will be received, free of charge, from clerks and others wishing to obtain posts in Egypt. Address, Secretary, British Chamber pf Commerce, Alexandria. [Advt.]

div.head: MOSLEM & CHRISTIAN.
div.p: EXTRACTS FROM TARAH BLUE BOOK.
THE UNSIGNED LETTER.

One of the most interesting passages in the "Correspondence respecting the Turco Egyptian Frontier in the Sinai Peninsula" is a letter addressed by Lord Cromer to Sir Edward Grey in May last giving his opinion as to the state of feeling existent in Egypt during the Turco- Egyptian crisis. It is as follows :—
Cairo, May 21, 1906.

Sir,—On occasions when, as in the present instance of the Akaba frontier question, a state of some tension exists between the Ottoman Government and the European Powers, I never fail to receive a large number of letters bearing on the subject, and written both by Egyptians and by Christians residing in Egypt. These communications, which are sometimes signed, but more frequently anonymous, usually contain little more than prayers from Christians to be protected against Moslem violence, or menaces of a more or less fierce nature from Moslems as to the consequences which will ensue from the continuance of a policy hostile to His Imperial Majesty the Sultan.

These letters, from whichever side they emanate, are seldom deserving of much consideration. They are generally inspired either by unreasonable fear or by excited fanaticism. Some days ago, however', I received an unsigned letter which, both on account of the nature of its cossets and the style of its composition, appears to me to call for some degree of attention. I have the honor to in close a translation herewith.

From the language of this document, and the signs of historical and literary education which are found in it, I should judge it to be written by a member of the Ulema class, not improbably of Turkish extraction.

You will observe that the writer, in very vigorous language, defines the position of the Egyptian. People under the influence of two conflicting sentiments - Damely, on the one hand, gratitude for material benefits conferred by Christian reformers, and, on the other hand, that unquestioning devotion which every true Moslem is taught, both by tradition and education, that it is his duty and his privilege to render to the Khalif.

It will be seen that, in the opinion of the writer, there is no doubt as to which of these sentiments carries, at least in a time of stresp, the greater weight with the Moslem population. Expression is given, in brief but cordial terms, to the feeling of gratitude which the Egyptians might be expected to entertain for acknowledged benefits received ; no attempt is made to deny or to depreciate the vaine of what Egypt h s gained from British advice and assistance ; on the contrary, it is implied that, so long as nothing honors to rouse Islamic feeling from its normally quiescent etate, the Egyptians are prepared to receive with some degree of thankfulness, or at least passively, the advantages which acorne to them from British and Christian administration.

When, on the other hand, it is publicly thought and said that active differences exist between the Christian Power and the re- presentative head of the Moslem faith, the former must not for a moment be deluded by the hope that the Moslem will betray his faith from motives of material gain. The views set forth in this letter are, I believe, those which predominate in the minds of a considerable number of Egyptian Moslems.

The frame of mind here indicated con- stitute?, I venture to think, an important fdû tor in the Egyptian situation. From an historical point of view, those unacquainted with the Oriental character might very pro- bably find it a matter for surprise that the Turkish name, or the prospect of reverting in any degree to a Turkish régime should inspire in Egypt any sentiment bat that of fear. From the conquest of that country by the Sultan Selim I. up to the time of Mehemet Ali Pasha, Turkish rule in Egypt was characterized by oppressive cruelty, and by a complete disregard for the ini e-ests of the people themselves. The country was relentlessly pluodered to fill the Treasury at Constantinople, acd to enrioh the Valis aud subordinate Ottoman officials who were named and removed in rapid succession by the Sub- lime Porte. There seems to be little in this state of things wh;ch the Egyptian can re- member with pleasure, or which he would desire to see restored.

Moreover, the condition of the snrronnding Provinces of Syria and Arabia should sntfice to prove to him that the methods of Government formerly employed in his own country still remain in force elsewhere, and that no change for the better has taken place in the system pursued ly a majority of the Turkish ruling class.

It most, however, be remembered that nearly a century has elapsed since the time when Egypt was ruled directly from Constantinople. None now living can speak from personal experience of the system of government which prevailed during that period; but few can remember to have heard an account of that system from their fathers ; whilst noue who are less than from 30 to •iO years old can speak from personal experience of the abuses which occurred prior to the inauguration of the reforms und r taken on the accession of the Khedive Tewfik. A generation is now growing up which has been born under happier suspices and in и the enjoyment of a more enlightened administration. The young men of this generation, who will soon constitute the leading t c'ass in the country, are very prone tore- r gard these traditions as pure inventions, or, g at least, as malicious exaggerations, spread t abroad from interested motives. Under these circumstances, Turkish rule appears to them c in a very false light. Closing their eyes to ' numerous object lessons around them, they 1 look only to the fact that they are them- 1 selves a Moslem people, placed to some extent J under Christian guidance which they would ' gladly see exchanged for the role of their 1 co-religion its, under the direct control of 1 the Head of their Faith. I do not, of courses, ' wish to be understood as implying that all, 1 or even a majority of the Egyptians of the j young or older generations are inspired by I this sentiment. But à strong leaven of it undoubtedly exists, and when skillfully and ' eloquently put forward it can hardly fail to spread among the mess of the people, whose i sympathies are a'.waye keenly alive to appeals directed from this quarter.

I need hardly point out the disastrous results which would inevitably ensue should these dreams ever be in any degree realized, or the bitter awakening which would await those who had indulged in them. À return to Turkish authority in this country in an active form could only mean ruin and suffering to the great mass of the Egyptian people History repeats itself, and those Egyptians who have studied the pages of the eloquent historian El Jabarti may remember the enthusiasm with which the population welcomed the army of the Grand Vizier Youssof Pasha when it entered Cairo on the departure of the French, and how soon that enthusiasm was sobered under the oppression and excesses of which they became the object. At the present day* should such an untoward event take place, its effects would be cruelly felt at once by every class, from the Khedive himself down to the humblest cultivator. That Turkish soldiers and Turkish officials possess many fine and admirable qualities is not disputed by any who know them well, but it cannot be said that the power of administering a subject province with justice and enlightenment is one of those qualities.

It may safely be asserted that in a short while nothing would remain of the present structure which has been so laboriously raised. The wealth of the country would be drained off by every form of extortionate taxation to replenish the exhausted offers of the Imperial Treasury, justice would become a thing of the past, and the mass of the population would learn by hard experience that, instead of being, as at present, the object of the keenest interest and solicitude to those in authority over them, they were regarded merely as a subject race whose doty and privilege it was to toil for the benefit of their masters. Even the upper classes, who might, perhaps, expect to profit by the change in virtue of their influence and position, would, I cannot doubt, share to a great extent the same fate. There is little sympathy between the Ottoman Turk and the Turoo-Egyptian Pasha, still less between the Turk and the rich fellah Notable. However well the Egyptian aristocracy might be treated in the first stage of the new order of things I am confident that in no long time they would find that they had exchanged the position of free citizens under a well-ordered government for that of subjects—in the fullest extent of the term—dependent on the pleasure of a practically irresponsible autocracy.

Nevertheless, in spite of there considerations, * which are too generally overlooked or little 0 understood, the names of the Khalif and his 1 Imperial capital still po sear the power to ^ awaken enthusiasm in the minds of many ® Egyptian Moslems. In so far as this sentiment 11 is founded upon pure devotion to religious * faith and loyalty to the Head of that Faith, t it cannot but excite some sympathy and b respect. Each is without doubt the frame of i mind of the writer of the inclosed letter. But 1 as regards those would-be leaders of Egyptian t thought who, without conviction and for their s own purposes, endeavor under the guise of f religious zeal to inspire the ignorant population ^ with a craving for Turkish rule, it is difficult I to speak too severely of their conduit. 1

It may confidently be said that there are many aspiration which may mors worthily and advantageously ooonpy the attention of ' the Egyptians, and towards the reasonable 1 attainment of which they may rely on the ' sympathy and coopération of their European advisers. But it must be fully reoogm'zsd that none of these aspirations could for a moment survive the accentuation of Turkish domination 1 :n the country. At the present time much is being said and written amongst the educated classe?, as to the development of self-governing institutions. I have frequently alluded to 1 the subject in my annual Reports. Here I need only say that, in process of time and with increasing enlightenment, it may perhaps be found possible to take some steps in this direction. But for the attainment of this end it is European assistance and guidance, Dot Turkish rale, which are required. The first result of any tightening of the Sultan's hold over Egypt would undoubtedly be the marked limitation and diminution of the authority of the Khedive. The semi-independent position of the Khedives of E;ypt has never been viewed with friendly eyes at Constantinople, and any opportunity of restricting and oar- tailing this independence would be gladly welcomed by the Suzerain Power. Under the conditions on which the Khedivate is now established, any attempt of this nature one'd, of course, be easily frustrated. But I should be happy to think that the Egyptians generally understood -as I am convinced that many of them do understand —that the only means by which they can hope to attain and to preserve that degree of administrative autonomy to which they now aspire, is by utilizing to the fullest extent the advantages which are now placed within their reach, and discouraging any iuaidious attempts to draw closer the bond which connects Egypt with the remainder of the Ottoman Empire. To this end all who dwell on Egyptian soil should, and I trust will, work together in a community of interest ; the Egyptian, both Moslem and Christian, and the European, who, whilst benefiting himself by the development of the country, has done, and is doing, so much to improve its resources and the material condition of its inhabitants. The real utility to Egypt of this latter category wap, as is well known, for many years partly paralyzed by the existence of feelings of mutual jealously and mistrust, but these feelings seem happily to be now on the wane, a better un- distending has been established, and I trust that a time may come when the Christian and Moslem residents in Egypt, the subjects of the Siltan and those of the Powers of Europe, will be cordially united in working for the common cause—the moral and material prosperity of Egypt and its inhabitants. But, I venture to repeat, the attainment of this object is not possible so long as a willing ear is lent to those who endeavor to instill into the minds of their countrymen a futile longing for the re-establishment of a past system, which could only result in disappointment, and even disaster, to all those who came under its influence.
1 have, &c,,
(Signed) CROMER.

div.head: THE MOSLEM'S WARNING.
div.p: The following is the text of the unsigned letter referred to above : —
In the name of God, &c.
To Lord Cromer, His Britannic Majesty's
Agent, the Reformer of Egypt.
(Translation.)

It is well known to you that the telegrams and newspapers appear each day, bringing nearer to ns, as it seems, the likelihood of grave differences between England and the Empire on matters relating to our land ot Egypt. But as the hopes of men for things desired are often disappointed, so also—for God is merciful to his creatures—Jo their fears of evil о mi to naught We pray the Almighty that it may be so now. I who write these lines in the name of "All the People of Egypt," am not a statesman or a man of great name ; my person and my dwelling are alike unknown to you, but I feel constrained, inasmuoh as I see many foolish acts committed, and hear many foolish words spoken, to stand on my feet and say the truth, as I think God has put it into my heart.

It is often said by fool", or by those who think thereby to make favour with the great, "The ourse of God upon the Christian"; "May hell consume the unbeliever, his household and his possessions." These are unbecoming words, for corses pollute the lips of the corset, and the camel lies in wait for the driver who mites him unjustly. At the head of this letter I call you by the name of "The Reformer of Egypt," and by this name you are known between the eeas and the deserts ; also many, but tot all, of the English who serve you have followed in your footsteps as wise children carry on the traditions of their father. He must be blind who sees not what the English have wrought in Egypt : the gates of justice stand open to the poor; the streams flow through the land are not stopped at the order of the strong ; the poor man is lifted up and the rich man palled down ; the hand of the oppressor and the briber is struck when outstretched to do evil. Our eyes see these things, and we know from whom they come. You will say : "Be thankful, Oh, men of Egypt! and bless those who benefit you"; and very many of us—those who preserve a free mind and are not ruled by flattery and guile—are thanking'. But thanks lie on the surface of the heart, and beneath is a deep well. While peaoa is in the land the spirit of Islam Bleeps. We hear the Imam ory out in the mosque against the unbelievers, bat his words pass by like wind and are lost. Children hear them for the first time and do not understand tlnm ; old men have heard them from childhood and pay no heed. But it is said. "There is war between England and Abdul Hamid Khan." If that be so, a change must come. The words of the Imam are echoed in every heart, and every Moslem hears only the ory of the Faith. As men we do not love the sons of Osman ; the children at the breast know фей works, and that they have trodden down the Egyptians like dry reeds. But as Modems they are our brethren ; the Khalif holds the saored places aud the noble relios. Though the Khalif were hapless as Bayezid, cruel as Murad, or mad as Ibrahim, he is the shadow of Qod, and every Moslem must leap up at his call as the willing servant to his master, though the wolf may devour his child while he does his master's work. The call of the Sultan is the oall of the Faith ; it carries with it the command of the Prophet (blowing's, &c.). I and many more trust that all may yet be peace ; but, if it be war, be sure that he who has a sword will draw it, he who has a club will strike with it. The women will ory from the house-tops, "God give victory to Islam !" You will say, ' The Egyptian is more ungrateful than a dog, which remembers the hoard that fed him. He is foolish as the madman who pulls down the roof tree of his house upon himself." It may be so to worldly eyes, but in the time of danged • to Islam, the Moslem tarns away from the things of this world, and thirsts only for the service of his Faith, even though be looks in the face of death. May God (His Name be glorified) avert the evil !
Signed by one, in the name of the people of Egypt.
Cairo, May 10, 1906.

div.head: NOTES FROM CONSTANTINOPLE
div.p: (From our Correspondent.)
Constantinople, July 16.

Commander C. Boaresoo, inspector of the Roumanian Maritime Service, will leave in a few days for St. Nazaire, where he will take over the new steamer Imperatiel Trajan, intend- ed for the new Constanza Constantinople Alexandria line. The vessel will arrive at Constanza on August 15, and great festivities will be held on the occasion of her christening. The inauguration of the line from Constanza to Constantinople and Alexandria has been fixed to take place on October 5.

It is stated that M. Philon, Hellenio Consul- General here, will be appointed Diplomatic Agent for Greece in Cairo. M. Naoum, the negotiator of the commercial treaty between Greeoe and Egypt, who was considered as likely to get this port, will be appointed diplomatic agent at Sofia, in succession to M. Zalacosta, who intends to retire unless the Hellenio Government gives him the promotion which he has asked for.
The Sultan ha9 given orders for the repair of the Mehemed Eini mosque and the adjoining mausoleum, at Tor.
A warrant has been is used for the arrest of Ali Hafi, who is charged with having gone to Egypt and issued prints of a seditions chv raoter.
The Hedjsz Railway Commission has re- ceived the sum of 200,000 piastres from the trustees of the late Menshawi Pasha, for the Hedjaz railway and the orphans of Ottoman soldiers.

div.head: FATAL FIRE IN TANTAH.
div.p: Early on Wednesday morning fire broke out in a house at Eafr Skarous, near Tantah. In a few minutes the flames spread to the whole building. The Moudir, the police authorities, and fire-brigade appeared on the scene early in the morning, and after a long struggle the fire was extinguished, but not before the house was destroyed. The proprietor, his wife, and his daughter, who was about to be married, were burned to death, and his two sons received serious injuries and were conveyed to hospital. The damages have not been estimated.

div.head: THE KOUBBEH ACCIDENT.
div.p: Hussein Bey Yawer, who was the only occupant of the carriage which collided with the end of the Eoubbeh Palace platform, is still in a serious condition. Besides the injuries which we mentioned in our description of the accident yesterday, he was scalded by the steam escaping from the engine, which toppled over after colliding with the buffers.

The unfortunate victim of the accident was conveyed to his home, where Dr. Shmeil and Dr. Rigazzi (who is acting fur Dr. Brossard at the Frenoh Hospital) diagnosed his injuries. Amputation, though called for by the nature of the injuries, was regarded as too dangerous, iu view of the general condition of the patient
We bear that the derailed locomotive could not be removed till late yesterday, the first crane sent down from Cairo and the second which came from Tantah being too weak to lift it.

div.head: UNION DISCOUNT CO.
div.p: We have pleasure in calling the attention of our readers to the last report and balance sheet of the Union Discount Company of London, Limited, which appeats in our oolumne to-day. This company is one of the most important Institutions doing a large and prosperous business in the London money market. The company discounts approved bank and mercantile acceptances ; receives money on deposit, and grants loans on approved negotiable securities at rates which can be ascertained on application at their office; and effects purchases and eales of Government stocks, shares and other securities on the usual terms. We understand they are doing a considerable business in this country.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
div.p: E. T. C. u. A MILITARY XI. OF R. D. F.
The military Xl.batted first and commenced badly, losing 6 wickets for 18 runs. However, some free hitting by Mr. French and Pte. Evans improved matters ; despite this they were all out for 99.
The E. T. C. commenced almost as badly as their opponents, losing 4 wkts. for 24, and despite a rather late but good effort by Blyth- mau, were all out for 75.
On the military XI. going in a second time, they were all out for 85, thanks to some good bowling by Hanley and Henley, and good fielding by all.

This left the E.T.C. the sporting task of making 110 runs in exactly an hour. They went for the runs and at 6.25 p.m. obtained them for the loss of four wickets, chiefly doe to some fine hitting by Hanley and Steele. Scores :

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Lord Edward Cecil Pasha, who is now at Alexandria, leaves for Cairo next Tuesday.
Lient. Col. A. W. Roper, R. E., has arrived in Egypt from England and assumed the duties of Commanding Royal Engineer.
It is reported from Paris that H. K Mohamed Pasha Sheriff, ex Under-Secret ту to the Ministry of Foreign Affaire, is seriously ill.

The funeral of the late Antoine Bey NahmaD, French consular ageit at Tantah, took place on the 18th inst., in the presence of the Moudir and the 1st dragoman of the French Consulate at Alexandria. The African Fathers conducted the funeral service.

div.head:
TSAR AND DUMA.
DISSOLUTION IMMINENT.
MANIFESTO TO PEOPLE.

div.p: A sensation has been cansed here by rumours that the Tsar has deoided to olose the Dama by fotoe of arms if it issues the manifesto to the nation demanding the na- tionalisation of land. His Majesty is also said to have arranged for Austro-German armed intervention in order to suppress insurrection. The latter report is ofiioially denied here and in Vienna, but the dissolution ot the Doma is generally regarded as imminent.
The Constitutional Democrats have submitte 1 a more moderate vision of the manifesto, which the Duma is at present disoussing, in order to avoid a confliot. (Reuter '■

The Duma, sitting until 2.30 in ths morning, adopted by 124 votes to 53, in spite of 101 absentees, the manifesto to the people, reject- ing the Government's agrarian programme and strongly favouring the expropriation of land- owners, admonishing the people to peacefully await the realisation of the Duma's labours. This is taken as a deoioive challenge to the Government. ( Pewter)

The rumour if the dissolution of the Duma is oausing great exoitement. Considerable reinforcements of troops are arriving from, the interior. The olodng of several newspaper offices has caused disorders. (Haetu >
The dock labourers, who were on strike, have resumed work owing to ths order of the Governor, threatening to exile them if they oontinued the strike. ( Rent*)

Mr. Albert Beit has left £1,200,000 in hie will for the promotion of railways and means of oommnnioation in Rhodesia, German Bast Afrioa, Portuguese East and West Afrioa, and other parts, aooording as the Capc-to-Cairo railway may traverse the country. (Itmtir)
Houbb of Lords.—Lord Fitzmanrioe stated that Great Britain had joined the Powers in making representations to Greece regarding the proceedings of Greek bands in Macedonia. {Reuter)
580 foreign deputies will attend the inter- parliamentary conference which is meeting in London on Monday. (Reuter)
Eolipae Stakes.—Llangibby 1. Beppo 2. Wombwell 3. (if euter)

div.head: PITH OF THE PRESS.
div.p: In a speech of nearly three'hours' duration Mr. Haldane yesterday expounded to the Honse of Commons the outline of bis scheme of Army reorganization. To grasp the details of that soheme is by no means alto- gether easy. Apart from the inherent diffi eulty and complication of the sutject, Mr. Haldane's exposition seems to have suffered scmcwhat from his anxiety to impress upon one section of the House that every mea- sure be was taking was simply and solely determined by the desire to secure increased military efficiency, and. at the same time, to impress , upon another section his horror of war, his bnrnipg desire for redaotion of military expenditure, and his anxiety to ena- ble this country to set a bright example to a Dot over responsive world by a le id in reducing our own de eusive strength Jn exchange for the serious redactions in our . strength and expansive power which he is , introducing, apart from those really connected j with genuine measures of reorgar:zitior, he has given us nothing more tangible than general expressions of bis ideas and vagne aspirations without any indication ss to how j these ideas and aspirations are to be mate- rialized in praotioe. (''Times.' )

There can be no two opinions about the im- portance of the speech in which Mr. Haldaue expounded the Army policy of the Govern- ment. This policy is too complicated, and in many respects too abstruse, to be submitted to anything like a hasty judgment. At any rate, it is well to begin with a recognition of two elementary faots ; the first is, that the organi- sation of our military foroes should be outside the pale of party politics ; and the second is that Mr. Haldane is incapable of doing con- soiously anything which threatens to reduce our Imperial defences below the safety-line. But at firBt glance the average taxpayer will be struck by the oontrast between Lord Roberts' warning on Monday—that our mili- tary foroes are absolutely inadequate for the defence of the Empire—and Mr. Haldane's proposal to reduce the strength of our Regular troops by twenty thonsaod men including the abolition of two Guards' battalions. ("Tele- graph.")

The speech represents the net result to be a foroe more eflioient for war than that now existing aod yet at the same time less costly. We have never read the statement of a Secretary of State for War who did not propose to give a more economical basis, save and ex- cept when Mr. Drodriok raised the soldier's pay. But before it will be possible to recognise We have never read the statement of a Secretary of State for War who did not propose to give a more economical basis, save and ex- cept when Mr. 'Brodriok raised the soldier's pay. Bat before it will be possible to recognise the increase of effuiency for war more informa tion will have to be forthcoming than can be gathered from yesterday's speech. (''Morning Post.")

Will Great Britain sacceed in modifying the present state of affairs by aiy other way than by having reoonrse to compulsory service 1 This question is a vital one for Great Britain. Exemption from service has aided the com- mercial development of bar young men to a high degree, and has given them a considerable advantage over foreigners of the same age. It also permits of expatriation at an early age. Whether to sacrifice this inestimable advan- tage, which has bestowed a kind of power on the nation, for the sake of a strong Army, necessary for the development and mainte- nance of a strong foreign and Colonial polioy, is the dilemma which Lord Roberts places before the British people. ("Tempp.")

Whatever defects time may disclose, Mr. Haldane's proposals have at least the merit of beiog based on sound business priuciples... When we come to his proposals e Ifsoting the Yeomanry and Volunteers we have to confess to a Biogle miagiviog. The introduction of the elective principle into the financial and administrative oontrol is an innovation that may have merits in the eyes of Home Rulers, but the history of all citizen armies oon'rolled by popular .representatives is full of warning, f''Daily Mail.")

The scheme has in it, we believe, the pro- mise of Bucciss, and it shonl-i give ns both economy and elficiency^.But it depends on the co-operation of the country, and especially of Mr. Haldane's snpporters in the Liberal Party. Let those who objeot to ''militarism''remem ber, as we said yes e -day, that it is not a question between army and no army, but bo- tween one kind of army and auother, and that if we are not to be delivered into the hands of the Conscriptionists, we are bound to show that the Voluntary system is snlfi :ient fur oar neads and to rally to its snpport.(''Westminster Gazette.")

The skill and Inoidity with which Mr. Haldane explained his scheme of Army reform d d Dot conoeal its faults or mitigate the sense of disappointment with which it was received in the House of Commons. It is with sincere regret that we note his failure to justify the hopes which had been bnilt on his distinguished ability and bis known desire to strengthen the military defences of the Em- pire. He had proclaimed the need for olear thinking, and demanded time to produce a matured plan. Yet the proposals with which he has associated his name bear every mark of confnsion and haste. For this unfortunate result we do not impate any personal fault to the Secretary for War. He was driven for- ward by an ardent group of extremists, who clamoured for instant and wholesa'e reduo tions on the Estimates ; and the plan now unfolded is evidently a compromise between the minimum which hi oousifers safe aod the maximum they will tolerate. ( 'Standard.")

Mr. Haldane's speech shows that he has inherited the optimism of his predecessors, but we hope that his native oantion will teach him to learn from their misadventures, and to beware of the glitter of fauoif al schemes. ("Tribune.")

The first seoret in obtaining either efficiency or eoonomy is to be dear about what yon want it for. Mr. Haldane's speech has the great merit of potting before the conntry, in terms which show a definite purpose in his own mind, and which every man can understand, precisely what our military forces are wanted fo*, and what function each branch of the services is meaDt to fulfil Mr. Haldane is working on the right lines. When onoe tli9 people know exictly what is wanted, they will, he be'ieves, be ready to do it "No compnlsior, but confidmce," is his motto. (' Dai'y Chronicle.") .

As we have so loug bien the victim of paper armios, we may be exonsed if we hesitate to believe that the present Secretary for War has solved the problem that has baltl id all his pre- decessors. We are still met by the old qaestioD, Where is the British soldier to come from 1 The great fait remains that at a moment when the armies of the world are striving feverishly to I , increase their nnmbers and efficiency, and whin the fature if hack with the practical oertainty of astrngglefjroir national existence, Mr. Haldane proposes to redace theefieotive strength of the British Army by 20,000 men. ("Globe.")

div.head: HIE PATRIARCH AND THE PORTE.
div.p: HIE PATRIARCH AND THE PORTE.

The reasons which have deoided Mgr. Ormanian, the Armenian Patriarch, to a-k the Saltan to relieve him of his office are exaotly the same as those which have always inspired hie complaints at the Porte ever since his election. The affairs of the Patriarchate are administered by several committees, which have charge of the schools, the hospitals, the orphanages, the ohnrches, and so on. These committees are nominated by an Assembly of Notables, cou- i sisting of one'hundred and forty mirnbjr , but this Assembly has not met for over ten years, in spite of the fffirts which have been made to obtain leave to do so. The oonsequence is that tin committees have never been renewed, and are now almost non-existent, since half of the members are dead, and many of the survivors are unfit for the work. Moreover, the Patriaroh has been refosed permission to appoint bishops in those vilayets to which the Armenian! have fled from the attacks of the Eords Promises have been continually made, bni as often broken, and now the Patriaroh seef nothing for it but the resignation of hi: office. The Porte has requested him to recon- sider his decision, promising that everything shall be settled in a short time. The Patriarch has consented not to press his resignation for a few diys, but if he does not get the Porte's promises in writing within a week, he will finally resign, as he has lost all authority over bis people owing to his inability to obtain even are jastioe from the Porte.

div.head: MOTHER'S EXPERIENCE
div.p: We have received a communication from Mrs. L. Lewis, of Hazeihnrat House, St. An- drew's Rd., Cogan, nr. Penarth, Wales, which is exceptionally interesting.

Just previous to the birth of her first ohild Mrs. Lewis beoame so ill with dropsy that her life was despaired of. The prematnre birth of her child, however, saved her, and the drop- sical swelliDgs went down somewhat. Bat at the second period of pregnancy the dropsy reappeared worse than ever, the water threaten- ing the patient's heart. A specialist and Mrs. Lewis's own doctor agreed that the case was hopeless, but the second child was providently born some mouths before its time, aod the mother's life again saved. The dootor then warned the patient that to attempt to rear children wonld co»t her her life, but at this time Mrs. Lewis heard of Doan's Baokache Kidney Pills, and began taking them. This medicine drove away every trace of dropsy and kidney trouble, and so bnilt up the patient's strength that her third child was born healthy and Btrong, and up till the last the mother wn able to perform her household duties.

It was on 12th April, 19(2. that Mrs. Lewis told os ot her cure, and on August 3rd, 1904— over 2j years later—she said : —I've nover bad 'lie lesat sign of dropsy or kidoey troable sinoe my cure by Dean's Pills. And I've more good news to tell you : twelve months ago I gave birth to another baby—and a fine little fellow he is !" Doan's Pills are special kidney help. When a cob', mimse of beer, spirits and tea, or any other cause, puts extra work on the kidnpys, Doan's Pills give the additional help needed ; when the delicate kidney tissue is weakened or ologgod, Doan's Pills strengthen and cleanse it ; when the bladder-walls and nrinary passages are irtlimed and coated with impurities, Doau's Pills allay the irritation and remove tho cansa, by driving out the clogging poisons.

div.head: THE BRITISH IN EGYPT.
div.p: KEÎjLAIIEEN'S change oe attitude.

There is no doubt that for nearly a decade Egypt has been generally regarded as a part of the world under British protection, where internal affairs have remained in a satisfactory state of peaoe and progress. This is probably owing to pnblio attention being centred on affairs in Sooth Africa and elsewhere. Bat now that a oertain amonnt of interest has been aroosed by the Tabah incident, and more recently by the outrage on British officers at Denishwai, the qoestion arises : Are affairs in Egypt in snch a peaceful and satisfactory condition as iB generally suppos- ed ! If anyone who is on the spot and who is able to res below the calm surface were asked this question, bis answer would cer- tainly be to the effeot that there is a very strong feeling of disaffection among certain of the lowerdass natives which if allowed to grow may become a danger to the country.

For some time oow it has been evident to English people living in Northern or Lowel Egypt, and particularly in Cairo, that the attitude of the lower olass natives is very different from what it used to be. In former years the Englishman was regarded by the Fellaheen, or native peastntry, with feelings of awe and with tha deepest respect, and this feeling instead of giving place, under the advantages of British ii.fluence, to friendship and goodwill, seems to he gradually growirg into dislike and contempt. This was made more appareot than ever by the attitude and conduct of the native population while the Tabah question was under discussion. This, perhaps, was only evident in Cairo and the large towns, hut when it is rememberei that vast numbers of countrymen corns in every day with their camels laden with goods for market from all parts of the country and spend their time at the cafés talking with their friends in the towa it is natural that the opinion of the town very soon becomes the opinion of the country.

It is difficult at first sight to understand why these feelings should have arisen, when, under British iotiaence, the country has emerg- ed from a state of oppression into one of opulence, and when justioe and order have taken ths place ot lawlessness and barbarity. Perhaps a solution may be arrived at when it is remembered that, up to comparatively re- cent years, from time immemorial the Egyptian had existed in a state of slavery, and had submitted without a murmur to all the ter- rible cruelties and injastioes of such a condi- tion ; but now there has sprung up a genera- tion which does not realise what the old régime meant, and, in the peace and prosperity of modern, times. has forgotten that it owes its present advantages to our influence. Edaoa- tion, however, has not advanoed at the same rate of progression—with the result that same rate of progression—with the resalt that the Fellaheen are as ignorant to-day, exoept perhaps, in the matter of making money, as they were in the old times of slavery. To return to a state of affairs in which the native regards the Englishman with feelings of fear oannot,cf ooarse.be advocated, bat, on the other hand, when a people has just emerged from a state of slavery, lack of firmness and the show- ing of unnecessary favour is sure to be m;s- understood by the ignorant classes and in- terpreted by them to mean weakness and fear ; and that is what has undoubtedly happened in Egypt.

The fellah, instead of regarding the English- man as his benefactor, has aotaally began to believe that be is afraid of him, and to con- sider as his right what has been only granted as an indulgence. If an example be needed it is necessary only to point to the Denishwai affair—where the natives regarded the wild pigeons as their own property, and when these were shot by English c fibers, who had as ma oh right to shoot them as the natives them- selves, took the law into their own hands, no doubt thinking that their action would be upheld. Before a remedy can be applied it is first necessary to discover the cause of the evil, and ths cause here is undoubtedly ignorance and want of education. Without education the finer instincts in a man lie dormant. It is only by educating the ignorant classes that they will, in time, realise the enormous ad- vantages they have reaped since England oc- cupied the country, and regard the presence of Englishmen from the right point of view. It is only by education that they will come to learn that to stretoh out the hand of friend- ship and goodwill is not a sign of fear and weakness.

The education of the masses is, of coarse, a very difficult question in every country. and the only way it can be accomplished is by the establishment of compulsory Government schools in every village or district in the coun- try, and in another ten years there would be a rising generation of frieni'y and intelligent people who would not take a delight in show- ing their indifference and disrespect for the English. How such a system could be carried out must be left to those who have studied the question ; but that a system of some kind is urgently required can admit of no doubt, if such affairs as that at Denishwai are to be made impossible ; and it is not only by the oarrying out of severe sentences, after such occurrences have tsksn place, that a remedy can be effeoted. ("Morning Post").

div.head: MUMMIES AND MAGIC.
div.p: STORY OF THE TOMBS OF OLD EGYPT. REVEALING THE PAST.
M. Gayet, the explorer of the tombs of Antinoe, is in Paris, where he has unwillingly persuaded himeelf to give an interview to a reporter of the "Matin."
This has been a great year for him, and he brings back, with other rarities several gijded mummies. None such in his knowledge are found in the museums of Europe, or even in the museum of Cairo.
There was, indeed, a gilded mummy shown in the exhibition of 1900, but it went back to Egypt to enrich some private collection.

But M. Gayet's enthusiasm is not kept for these gilded dead folk. He has the mummy which is called the "favourite of Antincii-i," and she is also the favourite of M. Gayet, who speaks lovingly of the tresses of her dark brown hair, clustered thick as clusters of black grapes.

Her very name has been given to M. Gayet, but it was not found by the common way by the searching of papyrus or the unriddling of inscriptions. Soon after the mammy of the favourite was first brmght to the light there came to M. Gayet an unnamed man, an adept in the hidden soiences.
Give this man an object to hold, and he will call before him its fi-st owner as a being who will speak with him.

Thus, with the aid of a magic mirror found in a tomb, whose very use was unexplained by the savants, he was able to describe to M. Gayet the mysterious spells and corjurations of the magioians of old, such as those whose rods became snakes at Pharaoh's feet.

An Egyptologist has his eyes open for frand, and M. Gayet put his adept to a crucial test. He gave him to hold in his hand a forged soarab, telling him that here was an anoient thing new,ly brought out of a tomb.
The adept held the scarab, and to the wonder of M. Gayet, who awaited tome guess- work tale of old Egypt, deBoribed feature by feature the fellah who had made it the week before.
To the wiz ird who had passed safely by such a test M. Gayet entrusted the ring of virgin gold which had lain two thousand years in the tomb beside the favourite of Antinoiis.
The seer blew upon it lightly to drive away the trace of later touches, and then pressed it against his forehead, closing his eyes.

He had never beheld the coartesan'smummy, but when he spoke his words brought before M. Gayet the favourite in her habit as she was wrapped for the tomb. He told how the Bacshai.tes danced a9 they followed the god's oar, of the orgies and hidden life of one who would for wantonness prick doves to the heart with the long cold pins that held up her hair
He knew even the name of the dead courte- san, and it was Arteminisia.
"But hush !" says M. Gayet to his inter- viewer. "If those gentlemen of the Academy of Inscriptions were to hear such thing.—"
The reporter reassures him, and hastens with the tale to his editor.

div.head: THE AUSTRALIAN MAILS.
div.p: When Mr. De»kin makes his statement in the Commonwealth Parliament on the subject of the new Australian mail oontraot, it will be found, says " The Shipping Gazette," that an entirely n6w complexion will be put on theagreement just conolnded with an important syndicate, represented in England by Sir James Laing and Sons, shipbuilders, of Sun- derland. It will be discovered that the present action of the Commonwealth Government iB fraught with the greatest possible importance to the future of Australasia, for, whether or not this iB the first move towards the citation of a State line of steamships to the Mother Country, the undertaking is one for whiob the bulk of the required oapital will be fur- nished by the Colonies themselves. In faot, Australia has set its heart on a mail servioe which it considers suited to its needs, and in particular the new departure is hailed with great satisfaction by the Labour Party in the Colonies.

Cables from Melbourne give the annual subsidy under the new oontraot as £125,000. As a matter of fact, the amount is little short of doable that figure, and for the reason that there are several contributors, altboagh these cannot be immediately specified. Nothing ap- prbaching this sum has ever previously been paid for a fortnightly service, from which it may be inferred that the conditions possess a certain novelty. For instance, not only is there to be a redaction of 60 hoars in the mail transit, partly owing to increased speed, and partly owing to the selection of Brindisi as the European mail port in place of Naples, but speoial provision is to be made far the carriage of cargo by the new fleet of eight or nine 16- knot steamers. Some of the Orient Company's boats engaged in the present mail service have it is stated, a deadweight oapaoity not ex- ceeding 1,500 tons. The new steamers, which will be built in British yards, will have a carrying oapaoity of as much as 8,000 tons, and it is to this oiroumstance that the syn- dicate looks for a considerable part of its profit.

There had been severe competition for the contraot just awarded. It emanated not only from the Orient Company, but in an even greater degree from shipping interests, no- minally or otherwise, financed on the other side of the Atlantic. As regards the Orient Company, it is sufficient to say that the dif- ference between their tender and that which has been accepted was so small as to be hardly worth consideration, and that the Orient and Royah Mail Companies, aoting together, would have got the oontraot but for the faot that the former company managed to alienate Colonial sympathy when the question of mail carriage was previously under consideration. The oa- pital of the new syndicate has been stated as £1,000,000, but we believe that is considerably in excess of the amount required.

Egyptian Mines Exploration.— Mr. C. J. Alford has fornix lied the following summary of the month's operations: Atallah Mine (Central Egypt Company)—June 20 : Main shaft down to 210 ft. in granite; timbering, including ladder-ways and partitions, completed to 185 ft. Semna Mice (Fatira Company) - June 10: Main shaft 1st level E. 63 ft., vein in face 64 in. wide, assays 5.25 dwt. gold per ton. 1st. level W. 77 ft., vein 54 in. wide, assays 67 -dwt., and at 75 ft., 36 in. wide, assays 13 dwt gold per ton. Main winze down 17 ft. below 1st level, vein wider than 5 ft. side of winze, assays at 5 ft. down 13 dwt., at 10 ft. 315 dwt., at 15 ft. 53 dwt. gold per ton. Values steadily increasing with depth. No. 1 Shaft lBt level W. 185 ft, vein in face 12 in. wide, with 34 dwt. gold per ton. No. 3 Shaft 1st level E. 146 ft., vein at 110 ft. 60 in. wide, with 13 dwt. gold per ton. at 145 ft. 84 in. wide 6.5 dwt. gold per ton. Work temporarily suspended.

Sudan Mines. — The engineer reports in a letter received the 9th inBt.: "Qabait Main drive south 10 ft. level. At 28 ft. reef exposed 9 ins. value 39 dwts ; at 31 ft. reef exposed 12 ins. value 26 dwts ; at 82 ft reef exposed 15 ins. value 10 dwts ; at 33 ft. reef exposed 22 ins, value 22.5dwts ; at 33 ft. reef exposed 26 ins, value 181 dwts; at 36 ft. reef exposed 60 ins. value 91 dwrs. Yesterday and to day nearly every piece pioked up contained visible gold. This morning praotically the whole face was reef, though only about two-thirds was solid quartz; the remaining schistose matter also contained some visible gold. The reef seems to be dipping rather steeper,about 45degs to 50 degs, but varies considerably." The next week's letter reported:—"At 5 ft. reef exposed 14 ins, value 70 dwts; at 11 ft. reef exposed 27 ins, value 101 dwts; at 14 ft. reef exposed 18 ins, value 10 dwts ; at 17s ft. reef exposed 16 ins, value 19.6 dwts; South drive—At the end of the south drive I have started a small croesont to the west and at 2 ft. have cut 12 ins of quartz, assaying 11.5 dwts."

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: To day bears a date which will bring many recollections to all ranks of the 2nd Battalion lloyal Inniskilling Fusiliers at Cairo, for it is the great holiday of the North ol Ireland.
It is officially intimated that Colonel St. Qaorge C. Henry, of the Egyptian Army, has been granted the local rank of Brigadier-Gene- ral during the absence on leave of the Sirdar.
Iustruotions have been issued for recruiting to be poshed hard in the recruiting area of the Royal Dublin Fusiliers, as a large number of men is required fof this regiment.

It is stated that the Financial Secretary to the Admiralty will not make his promised statement on the Navy Estimates in the House of Commons on Friday next, as previously arranged. It was understood that Mr. Edmond Robertson would then have officially annonnced that the Cabinet had deoided to reduce this year's ship building programme by abandoning one of the two Dreadnoughts, which it was originally intended to commence this autnmn. It is understood that at the last moment an Important member of the Board of Admiralty 'has decisively refussd to acquiesce in this proposed reduction. The Prime Minister has consequently postponed the consideration of the ship building vote in the House of Com- mons for a fortnight in order to gain time for a' fair disoussion of the matter the Cabinet. Two foots have had an important influence on naval opinion.' Tn the first plaoe, Germany and France in the next two years will lay down four and six Dreadnoughts,respectively— vessels tar excelling in fighting power and speed any battleships now in commission in the British fleet. In the second place, the dramatic oonolnsion of the naval manœuvres, when Vice-Admiral Sir William May, in his passage from Ushant to Scarborough, de- monstrated the immense strategical importance of speed, has impressed naval officers with the seriousness of the outlook if Great Britain lags behind in the construction of battleships of maximum gun power and the highest possible speed.
On promotion, Commander A. G. E. Hill has been re-appointed to the oommand of the CalypBO, drillship at Newfoundland for the Naval Reservists.

Prior to the battleship Implacable leaving the Mediterranean for England to be recom- missioned, she was visited by Lori Charles Beresford. He oomplimented Captain Patey 1 and all ranks on the very high state of efficiency 1 in which he found the ship. He looked upon 1 the Implaoable as seooud to none, and not only a oredit to the Mediterranean Fleet, but to 1 the whole British Navy.

The battleship Dominion will proceed to Canada next month to receive a presentation from the ladies of the Dominion. In addition to Halifax, several ports will be visited by this very fine speoimen of marine arohiteoture.

Earl Roberts delivered in the House of Commons, la«t Tuesday, a speech on the nation's unpreparedness for war, which should receive careful consideration. His opinion on the qaestion of national defence is entitled to much weight, and when he tells the country that it is not prepared to carry on a war with a great military Power it is time that something should be done. What he urges as essential to national' safety is that theije should be a large and powerful reserve, se that daring a war our army could be expanded as the necessity arose. This reserve, he thinks, can best be provided by some system of oompulsory military training. He does not say compulsory j service, or conscription. Some people trust altogether to the navy, bat the best naval expert will not guarantee the country against military raids, which, if not immediately defeated, might cause panio, and inflict a loss on the nation. Lord Roberts asked the House to remember that Great Britain had never carried on a war that was waged on the sea alone, and that apart from the late war in South Africa, she had never won a considerable campaign on land by her own independent efforts. The great victoriei of Marlborough and Wellington were won with the aid of foreign troops ; but it is not oertain that in the future we shall be able by alliances or by subsidies to obtain such military aid. It is better, therefore, for the country to have a B itish foroe to which it* can trust. As Lord Roberts reminded the House, the nation which cannot defend its possessions must inevitab'y perish. Our army at present is strong enough to defend the United Kingdom against any force which might escape the vigilanoe of the navy : but it might not be in the United Kingdom at the time. It might be on the Indian frontier repelling a Russian invasion. In that case the United Kingdom, apart from the navy, would be almost defenceless, and it would also be unable to make good the waste which would ooour in a war in Asia. These are the defects which his Lordship is pointing out as dearly and foroibly as he oan, in the hipe that the publio will call upon the Govern- ment to find a remedy. The remedy which he recommends is a system of universal military training. He asks the nation to recognize that it is the duty of evjry able bodied man to fit himself to take part in the defenoe of the country in a great national emergency. It is criminal fir a nation, he asserted, and espe- cially oriminal for its rulers, to enter upon a war, without having trained soldiers suffi- cient in number to justify their having every reasonable hope of carrying it to » successful issue.

div.head: PNEUMONIA FOLLOWS LA GRIPPE PE-RU-NA RECOMMENDED.
div.p: A well-known business man and an old resident of aylermer gives his experince with use of pe-ru-na as a curatuve and preventive of la Grippe and Colds.
Mr. T. Barnecott, West Aylmer, Ontario, Can., -writes:

"Last winter I was ill with pneumonia after having la grippe. I took Peruna for two months, when I became quite well, and I can say that any one can be cured by it in a reasonable time and at little expense. Every time I take a cold, I take some Peruna, which makes me well again.

"I also advised it for my daughter who was so ill with prostration that sho could not follow her trade of dressmaking. A bottle of Peruna made such a change in her that she has been able to follow her business ever since.
"I also induced a young lady, who was all rundown and confined to the house, to take Peruna, and after taking Peruna for three months she is able to follow her trade of tailoring. V
"I can recommend Peruna for all such who are ill and require a tonie."
Every year, during the Inclement weather of winter, there is an epidemic of catarrh. The disease is really ca- tarrhal in nature, but from the form it assumes, has been commonly termed the 'grip.'

It is very tenacious when it once gets a firm hold upon the system and, in ad- dition to a thorough, systemic catarrh remedy, a great deal of patience and persistence in the treatment are ac- quired to eradicate the disease.

Peruna, an internal catarrh remedy, is one of the best medicines ever de- vised to meet the exigencies of these cases. The large number of oommend- atory letters received by Dr. Hartman, the inventor of Peruna, in behalf of his remedy is proof sufficient of its vain* as a reliable medicine for the 'grip.'

For special directions everyone should read "The His of life," a copy of which surrounds each bottle. Parana is for sale by all chemists and druggists at five shil Hugs per bottle or six bottles for twenty-five shillings.

div.head: L'ARBRE DE LA VIERGE
div.p: Nous annoncions, il y a quelques jours que l'arbre de la V:erge venait de se briser. En effet, a environ nn mètre eu dessas da sol. à l'endroit ch il se séparait en deux, une cassure s'est produite et la moitié droite da l'arbre s'est abattue. Cet aooident ost du à la vétusté du végétal dont le bois chaque jour se désagré- geait et résistait moins. Ou a de suite étayé l'antre branohe, essayant ainsi da préserver la seconde moitié de ce vénérable sycomore.

Cet arbre est nn très vieux ficus sycomorus, la vrai sycomore d'Orient, qui ne ressemble en rien à l'espèce d'érable eounae en France sous oe nom. Sou tronc meiare sept mètres de oirconférenoe à sa sortie dn sol. Quant à son fige, il nous est donné par des récita du temps. Le P. Bernardin Amico vit, en 1596, nn arbre dont le trono avait la forme d'un Y renversé. Une moitié du trono de cet arbre se détacha en 1656, l'antre moitié tomba en 1656. L'arbre aotne1, une bouture de son prédéces- seur fat, dit-on, planté en 1672, il aurait donc actuellement 234 ans. Si l'on admet nne durée analogue pour chaque sujet, le syco- more qui est en train de disparsWe serait douo le septième ou lo huitième descendant de oelni qui abrita la Vierge et l'Euiant de son ombrage.
Oui mais, disent les incrédules, comment a-t-on pn déterminer que o'est sous cet arbre et non sons nn autre que se reposa la Sainte- Famille 1
Oui mais, disent les incrédules, comment a-t-on pn déterminer que o'est sous cet arbre et non sons nn autre que se reposa la Sainte- Famille 1

L'Evangile apocryphe de l'enfance du Sau- veur répond : En sortant d'Hé'iopolis, les divins exilés se dirigèrent vem on eyoomore aitné près d'nne souroe d'eau douce. Or, une seule souroe existait dans les environs, c'était celle qui ne tarda pas à devenir célèbre, grâce à la propriété qu'avaient ses eaux de faire pousser le baumier. Auoune autre eau en Egypte n'était susceptible de faire oroltre l'arbuste au précieux parfam. Grâce à cette particularité la souroe et, par conséquent, l'arbre ont pu être identifiés.
La vénération dont on entoure cet arbre remonte aux premiers siècles de l'église. Les chrétiens élevèrent udo basilique en cet en- droit, monument qui a disparu an moment de la oonqoête musulmane.

La iête de la dédioaoe de cette église est restée dans le oalendrier Copte et o'est même lh l'origine de la traditionnelle promenade du Cham-el-Nessim. Les Coptes, autrefois se réu- nissaient pour cette iête h Mostorod, passaient la nuit en prières et le lendemain, après avoir entendu la messe, se rendaient à l'arbre vénéré. Les plus riches d'entr'eux donnaient des moutons et la journée se passait an grand air en jeux et en festins. C'est lh, parait il, l'ori- gine de la coutume d'aller ce jour lh joyeuse- ment festoyer h la oampagne.

Une circonstance locale a pu attirer parti- culièrement l'attention des chrétiens sur cet arbre. Tout proche de Matarieh, dans le grand temple do Soleil d'Héliopoli», était un arbre sacré, vénéré entre tous, le Asht, arbre de vie, sur les feuilles duquel les dieux gravaient les noms des rois pour l'éternité. Serait-il éton nant que le voisinage de oet arbre cé èbre ait donné l'idée aux premiers chrétiens d'entourer d'une vénération publique, de o> server aveo un soin jaloux l'arbre de Matarieh qui avait abrité de ses feuilles celui qui disait : "Je suis la vie :

Les légendes se pressent, nombreuses, autour de ce syoomore. Citons parmi les plus oonnues oelle qui veut que la Sainte Famille étant poursuivie par des malfaiteurs, le trono de l'arbre s'ouvrit, lui offrant un refuge et la dérobant h leur vue. On raconte aussi que ne trouvant pas de cabane pour se loger Marie Joseph et l'Enfant s'assirent, fatigué) et abat- tus au pied de l'arbre, aussitôt celui ci s'ouvrit miraculeusement depuis les raciuesjusqu'h mi- hauteur do trono, leur ménageant ainsi un abri dont ils profilèrent plusieurs jours.On dit aussi que ses fruits se multiplièrent et mûrirent de façon inusitée pour que les pauvres exilés pussent s'en nourrir. Mais on n'en finirait pas s'il fallait rapporter toutes les légendes, tou- ohantes ou puériles dont on entoure ce lieu.

Ce qui parait certain, c'est qs'il fut toujours considéré avec un grand respeot, tant par les musulmans que par les chrétiens et fut de tous temps visité par de nombreux pèlerins, parmi oeux-oi, citons K'éber qui, le lendemain de la bataille d'Héliopolia où avec ses 10,009 hom mei il avait écrasé 80,.00 Turc», vint visiter l'arbre de la Vierge et iusoriie son nom sur une branohe, de la pointe de son épée. J.D.

div.head: Banco di Roma
div.p: AVIS

Le Banco di Rima est autorisé à recevoir h ses guichets du 21 au 24 juillet les souecrip- tions à l'émission de 20.CO0 actions sur les 80.000 formant le capital Booial de L. It 2.000.000 de la sooiété italienne "Hermès" pour la construction d'automobiles.

Par suite d'un oontrat passé aveo une sooiété belge, la sooiété Hermès s'est assuré, pendant les trois premiers exeroices, une vente annuelle d'an moins 500 voitures, donnant à elle seule un bénéfice de L. It. 750.000.
Les actions de 25 lires italiennes nominales sont émises à L. It. 75.
Pour renseignements détaillés s'adresser an Banoo di Roma.
